todos.title: Leonardo Da Vinci’s Vitruvian Man
todos.body: We will never devise any invention more beautiful, nor more simple, nor more to the purpose than Nature does.

todos.title: John Naisbitt
todos.body: We are drowning in information but starving for knowledge.

todos.title: Hebbian Learning
todos.body: Two neurons that fire at the same time wire together.

todos.title: Second Law of Thermodynamics
todos.body: There is inevitable decay in closed system.  Keep systems open, tear down walls to growth.

todos.title: Vannevar Bush
todos.body: The summation of human experience is being expanded at a prodigious rate, and the means we use for threading through the consequent maze to the momentarily important item is the same as was used in the days of square rigged ships.

todos.title: Miller’s Law
todos.body: The observation, also by George Armitage Miller, that the number of objects an average person can hold in working memory is about seven. [3]

todos.title: Brin & Page
todos.body: The number of documents in the indices has been increasing by many orders of magnitude, but the user’s ability to look at documents has not.

todos.title: Moravec’s Paradox
todos.body: The hard problems are easy and the easy problems are hard.  Referring to artificial intelligence where a computer can do complex algorithms difficult for humans but cannot do simple things like tell you how they feel.

todos.title: Weiner – Geography of Bliss
todos.body: Seventy percent of happiness can be attributed to relationships with people.

todos.title: Fractal Theory
todos.body: Repeating patterns that display at every scale.

todos.title: Community Problem
todos.body: People need an identifiable spatial unit to belong to and are more likely to congregate in places with people of their clusters.  A person, group, space, place, product, or industry can only have a relationship with another object via a category other than itself (Ex. A person can ony have a relationship with another person either through a group, space, place, product, or industry).

todos.title: Strength Of Weak Ties
todos.body: People learn the most from contact and experiences outside of their circle.

todos.title: Synchronization
todos.body: Over time objects will start to work together in intertwined systems.

todos.title: Link-Cluster Conjecture
todos.body: One can infer the meaning of an object by looking at its neighbors.

todos.title: Rational Expectations
todos.body: It is difficult to profit from widely anticipated or predictable, events, since rational actors would already have taken the action necessary to arbitrage any such opportunities.

todos.title: Thinking Brains
todos.body: In order for computers to think, the silicon-based binary logic will have to morph to carbon-based chemistry/neurology.

todos.title: Fractional Importance
todos.body: If somebody has a relationship to you, you get a fraction of the importance or popularity that they have.

todos.title: Social Group Size
todos.body: Humans on average know 148 people (strong stable relationships).  95% confidence interval is 100 to 230.

todos.title: Hoteling’s Problem
todos.body: Businesses tend to cluster and end up competing with each other instead of spreading out.  Franchises have more ability to cluster but new local shops should separate themselves.

todos.title: Pareto Principle, Zipf’s Law, 80/20, Power Law
todos.body: A minority of causes, inputs, or effort usually lead to a majority of the results, outputs, or rewards.  A very small set of words makes up the vast majority of actual usage.  See Brown Corpus (1964).  Long-Tail – 80% that adds little value.

todos.title: Compounding Errors/Swiss Cheese Mistakes
todos.body: Error that are greater than the summation of the individual mistakes.
